title: Practical
text:
Tidy factor order
In this dataset, experience has a natural order from junior to senior and term has a natural order from winter to autumn.
 Reorder the levels of experience and season.

tutor <- tutor %>%
  mutate(experience = factor(experience,
                             levels = c("novice","mid","expert")),
         term = factor(term,
                             levels = c("winter", "spring", "summer", "autumn")))

 Why is it helpful to make the order explicit before plotting?
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
section: Create a date from year and term
text:
Create a date from year and term

We’ll create a single date column representing the first month of each academic term (Winter=Jan, Spring=Apr, Summer=Jul, Autumn=Oct).
 Use case_when() to map term → month, then combine with ym().

tutor <- tutor %>%
  mutate(month = case_when(
    term == "winter" ~ 1,
    term == "spring" ~ 4,
    term == "summer" ~ 7,
    term == "autumn" ~ 10
  ),
  year_month = ym(paste(year, month)))  # Date at first-of-month

 Check the new variable.

tutor %>% 
  select(year, term, month, year_month) %>% 
  head()

# A tibble: 6 × 4
   year term   month year_month
  <int> <fct>  <dbl> <date>    
1  2021 winter     1 2021-01-01
2  2021 winter     1 2021-01-01
3  2021 spring     4 2021-04-01
4  2021 spring     4 2021-04-01
5  2021 summer     7 2021-07-01
6  2021 summer     7 2021-07-01

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 1: Mean satisfaction over time
 Plot how student_satisfaction changes over year_month with a line and a light uncertainty ribbon depicting mean_se (standard error of the mean). Label the x-axis date as year-month.








 Does satisfaction tend to increase or decrease across years? Any clear term-to-term pattern?

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 2: Compare policies over time
 Plot how student_satisfaction changes over year with different lines / uncertainty ribbons in different colors for policy.








 Do the policies diverge or converge over time?

title: Practical
section: Exercise 3: Avoiding spaghetti — facet by experience
text:
Exercise 3: Avoiding spaghetti — facet by experience
What if we wanted to look at how the change in student_satisfaction by policy over year differs across tutors with different levels of experience? This would be a lot to cram into one plot - multiple lines would overlap and make them difficult to disentangle.
When multiple groups overlap, it can be easier to facet.
 Adapt your code from the previous exercise to facet by experience. Recall that the default facets will show plots horizontally side-by-side, but you can show them vertically by setting nrow to the number of facets (here, the number of experience levels, which is 3). Consider whether it is easier to perceive trends and differences when panels are organized horizontally versus vertically.
 Do the different experience levels show similar effects of policy over time? How does uncertainty / variability influence your perception of effects (if any)?
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
section: Exercise 4: Parse "mmss" into a time variable
text:
Exercise 4: Parse "mmss" into a time variable
The mmss column is a character string like "03:48.4". We’ll parse it into a proper time class for plotting.
 Generate a new variable in the tutor dataset: use lubridate::ms() (minutes/seconds) to create a variable called mmss_period for nice axis formatting.

tutor %>% 
  select(metric, mmss, mmss_period) %>% 
  head()

# A tibble: 6 × 3
  metric       mmss      mmss_period
  <fct>        <chr>     <Period>   
1 wait_time    2570:45.9 2570M 45.9S
2 session_time 36:22.3   36M 22.3S  
3 wait_time    2451:01.0 2451M 1S   
4 session_time 26:36.6   26M 36.6S  
5 wait_time    3524:16.3 3524M 16.3S
6 session_time 35:24.3   35M 24.3S  


 Why did we force mmss to character when reading the CSV? What could go wrong if the import guessed a time type automatically?
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
section: Exercise 5: Plot time metrics over years
text:
Exercise 5: Plot time metrics over years
Look at how wait time changes from one year to the next
 Filter the tutor dataset to just metric == "wait_time" and plot mean mmss_period by year with a ribbon.
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 6: Compare wait_time vs session_time

We’ll use the metric column to show how wait_time and session_time change over year.
Note that the ranges of wait_time and session_time are different: wait_time tends to be on the order of days, whereas session_time tends to be on the order of minutes. This will cause problems if we use a common y-axis for both. Here, first create the problematic plot, then edit it to solve the problem.
 Plot means and uncertainty ribbons for mmss_period by year, faceting by metric so that wait_time and session_time appear as different panels.








 See how it is very difficult to see changes in session_time, and the large amount of blank white space for wait_time. Why does this happen?
 Within facet_wrap, set scales = "free_y" to allow different y-axis ranges for the two panels.
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
section: Exercise 7: Facet by metric, color by experience
text:
Exercise 7: Facet by metric, color by experience
Now let’s add separate lines to see trends in wait_time and session_time for each experience level.
 Adapt your code for the previous exercise to color the lines and fill the ribbons based on experience.








 How do changes in wait_time and session_time differ across experience?
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 8: Drawing attention with highlighting
What if we want to focus on experts versus non-experts, and de-emphasize differences between tutors with mid or novice levels of experience?
 Create a new variable to highlight expert vs others using mutate and ifelse. Adapt your plot from the previous exercise to: (1) color and fill based on your new highlighting variable, and (2) group lines based on the experience variable. Set the scale_color_manual() and scale_fill_manual() values to choose colors that emphasize experts (e.g., expert in blue, non-experts in gray).








 Do experts differ systematically from other groups in wait_time and sesion_time trends?

Now let’s see how differences between policies in trends over time differ across agents with different levels of seniority.

 Use mutate to specify the order of the seniority factor levels as junior, mid, senior.

text:
Exercise 4: Parse time values
The mmss column stores durations like "06:30.7" or "116:08.0" as character strings.
 Convert mmss into a time variable called mmss_period using ms(), then convert mmss_period into an h:m:s-format time variable using hms::hms().

The dataset has three time metrics (first_response, handle_time, resolution_time) on very different scales.

 Plot the changes in mmss_hms over year with separate lines for policy and separate facets for metric. Free up the y-axis ranges as needed.

title: Overview
text:
This week you will learn how to customize your plots for clarity and appeal. Note that the preparation for this week includes multiple chapters from the module textbook, but each one is quite short.

Learning objectives
The successful student will be able to:

customize plot labels and axes to be clear and readable
polish the appearance of plots to make labels legible, reduce clutter, and increase visual appeal
combine multiple facets and plots to help the viewer synthesize and compare patterns

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
From last time

Time series and line graphs
Multiple groups & avoiding “spaghetti” plots
Working with dates (lubridate)
Line graphs for ordered variables (dose, distance, intensity)

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Content so far: Explore


We’ve been learning how to create different kinds of plots
Focus has been on mechanics of getting data into a plot
The plots we’ve made so far are good enough if we want to explore data ourselves

See what patterns exist in the data
Probe for issues to consider in analyses, like outliers


But they haven’t been optimised for communicating with other people

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Content going forward: Explain

Our plots should:

Draw the viewer’s eyes to the key pattern
Be easy to understand

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Content going forward: Explain


Producing viewer-friendly plots:

Use clear, readable labels
Use elements like color to highlight key patterns
Reduce clutter
Avoid redundancy (e.g., same variable labeled in axis and legend)
Use facets or multi-panel layouts to facilitate comparisons

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Two base plots

# Scatter (continuous x/y + color by group)
p_scatter <- psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = stress_score, y = sleep_hours)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = diagnosis))

# Bar (grouped mean + fill by group)
p_bar <- psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = diagnosis, y = stress_score)) +
  stat_summary(aes(fill = diagnosis), fun = "mean", geom = "bar")

  theme_bw() +

    legend.position = "top",

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Today

Labels with labs()


scale_*_* to customize breaks, labels, limits, and colors
Polishing visuals with theme()

Annotations, text, and direct labeling for clarity
Faceting: facet_wrap, facet_grid, and patchwork

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Annotations & direct labeling









Right now, one of the things that leaps out from this plot is that people with a diagnosis of anxiety or depression have higher stress scores
But if someone wanted to know what the exact scores for each group were, they’d need to try to mentally line up the heights of the bars with the y-axis.
If we want those exact values to be something that’s easy for the reader to see, we can label them on the graph.

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Annotations & direct labeling
geom_text()

# Get mean stress scores for each group
bar_means <- psych_df %>%
  group_by(diagnosis) %>%
  summarise(mean_stress = round(mean(stress_score, na.rm = TRUE), 1))

# Add a geom_text 
p_bar +
  geom_text(data = bar_means, # use the tibble we generated
            aes(x = diagnosis, y = mean_stress, label = mean_stress), # set the aes
            vjust = -0.3, size = 5) # shift up and make bigger

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Annotations & direct labeling









Now let’s go to this plot.
Perhaps here, we want to make it really easy to see which points correspond to each diagnosis, without people having to look at the legend.
So maybe we’d want to put nice clear labels in the middle of each group to label it as anxiety, depression, none
that geom_text might not be ideal because it might be difficult to read text on top of the points
so we’ll use something slightly different called geom_label to format the text in a nice labeled box

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Annotations & direct labeling
geom_text()

# Calculate where the center of each group lies on the
# stress_score (x-axis) and sleep_hours (y-axis) variables
group_centers <- psych_df %>%
  group_by(diagnosis) %>%
  summarise(
    stress_center = mean(stress_score, na.rm = TRUE),
    sleep_center  = mean(sleep_hours,  na.rm = TRUE))

p_scatter +
  geom_label(data = group_centers,
             aes(x = stress_center, y = sleep_center, label = diagnosis, color = diagnosis),
             show.legend = FALSE, 
             size = 5, label.size = 0.25) +
  theme(legend.position = "none") # get rid of the redundant legend

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Today

Labels with labs()


scale_*_* to customize breaks, labels, limits and colors
Polishing visuals with theme()

Annotations, text, and direct labeling for clarity
Faceting: facet_wrap, facet_grid, and patchwork

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Faceting
compare groups without clutter

p_scatter +
  stat_smooth(aes(color = diagnosis), method = "lm") #add regression line per group

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Faceting: wrap
compare groups without clutter

p_scatter +
  facet_wrap(~diagnosis) + #facet by diagnosis
  stat_smooth(aes(color = diagnosis), method = "lm") +
  theme(legend.position = "none", #facet labels make diagnosis legend redundant
        strip.background = element_blank()) #remove gray background of facet labels

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Faceting: grid
compare groups without clutter

p_scatter +
  facet_grid(sex~diagnosis) + # rows and columns
  stat_smooth(aes(color = diagnosis), method = "lm") + 
  theme(legend.position = "none",
        strip.background = element_blank())

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Faceting: grid
revise labels

p_scatter +
  facet_grid(sex~diagnosis, 
             labeller = labeller(sex = c(Female = "Sex: Female", Male = "Sex: Male")) ) + # label rows
  stat_smooth(aes(color = diagnosis), method = "lm") + 
  theme(legend.position = "none",
        strip.background = element_blank())

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Faceting: grid
revise labels

p_scatter +
  facet_grid(sex~diagnosis, 
             labeller = labeller(sex = ~ paste("Sex:", .x))) + # label rows
  stat_smooth(aes(color = diagnosis), method = "lm") + 
  theme(legend.position = "none",
        strip.background = element_blank())

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Patchwork: combine multiple plots

library(patchwork)

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Patchwork: combine multiple plots
horizontal

p_scatter + p_bar


Uses arithmetic-like notation to combine plots in a readable way

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Patchwork: combine multiple plots
vertical

p_scatter / p_bar

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Patchwork: combine multiple plots
nested

p_scatter | (p_scatter / p_bar)

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Patchwork: combine multiple plots
label

p_scatter + p_bar +
plot_annotation(tag_levels = 'A')

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Summary

Use labs() to control labels (title, subtitle, caption, axes, legend titles).
Use scale_*_* to control how scales are used/shown
Use theme() to control presentation (grid, legend, typography)

Emphasize clarity with annotations and direct labels.

Use facets and patchwork to structure comparisons

title: Independent Study to Prepare
text:
Advanced Customizations
To prepare for diving into this week’s topic, advanced customization:

Read Data Visualization Ch 20 - 24. Note: This might seem like several chapters, but they are each very short.

You may also make progress on the DataCamp assignment for the following week:

Communicating with Data in the Tidyverse - Chapter 3 Introduction to RMarkdown

title: Practical
text:
In this practical you’ll build a small Quarto project from scratch and create a mini HTML report based on the wellbeing dataset, using the ideas from Seminar 8:

Setting up a project folder with a subfolder for data
Creating a .qmd report file inside an RStudio project
Writing a YAML header for an HTML report
Adding a setup chunk that loads packages and data
Writing sections using Markdown (headings, paragraphs, lists)
Adding code chunks that generate tables and figures
Using chunk options (echo, include, fig-cap, out-width)

Inserting inline code (e.g., for sample sizes) in the text
Rendering the report and dealing with common errors

By the end, you should have your first complete Quarto report for this module, using a dataset on sleep and wellbeing.

Practicals are not a test. It is expected that you often don’t know how to start, make a lot of mistakes and need help. It is expected that you are familiar with independent study content before the workshop. However, you need not remember or understand every detail as the workshop should build and consolidate your understanding. Tips:

don’t worry about making mistakes

don’t let what you can not do interfere with what you can do

discussing code with your neighbours will help

look things up in the independent study material

look things up in your own code from earlier workshops

there are no stupid questions







Key



These four symbols are used at the beginning of each instruction so you know where to carry out the instruction.
 Something you need to do on your computer. It may be opening programs or documents or locating a file.
 Something you should do in RStudio. It will often be typing a command or using the menus but might also be creating folders, locating or moving files.
 Something you should do in your browser on the internet. It may be searching for information, going to the VLE or downloading a file.
 A question for you to think about and answer. Record your answers in your report or script for future reference.

title: Practical
section: Exercise 1: Create a Quarto project folder
text:
Exercise 1: Create a Quarto project folder
In this exercise you will create a new folder for a mini Quarto project, add a data/ subfolder for the CSV, and turn it into an RStudio project.
 In the Files tab in the lower right pane, click on the ... on the right (this should say “Go to directory” when you hover over it). Clicking the ‘…’ will open the Go to folder window. Navigate to a place on your computer where you keep your work for this module (for example your data-visualisation-in-r folder). Click Open.
 In the Files tab, click on New Folder. Give the folder a short, sensible name for this project, such as week-8-report.
We’ll refer to this folder as project_name/ in the instructions below.
This is the first step for setting up the structure for your project folder. Upon completing the steps below, your project folder should ultimately look like this:
project_name/
  project_name.Rproj
  wellbeing_report.qmd
  data/
    wellbeing_dataset.csv
 In RStudio, follow these steps create an RStudio project inside this existing folder:

Click on the drop-down menu on the top right where you see a little blue cube and the words Project: (None) (alternatively, if you already opened a project, you will see the name of your current project here)

Choose New Project

Choose Existing Directory

Browse to your new project_name/ folder and select it

Click Create Project


RStudio will create a file called something like project_name.Rproj inside your folder.
 The Files tab in the bottom right pane will now be rooted at project_name/. Click New Folder again and create a subfolder called data.
You should now have:
project_name/
  project_name.Rproj
  data/
 Download the wellbeing dataset:

wellbeing_dataset.csv

 Save wellbeing_dataset.csv inside the data subfolder of your new project:
project_name/
  project_name.Rproj
  data/
    wellbeing_dataset.csv
 Why is it helpful to keep the data file inside the project folder, rather than somewhere else on your computer?

title: Practical
section: Exercise 2: Create a Quarto report file
text:
Exercise 2: Create a Quarto report file
Next, you’ll create a new Quarto document (a .qmd file) inside the project.
 In RStudio, go to File → New File → Quarto Document…

Under Title, enter: Sleep and Wellbeing Across Groups

Under Author, you can put your name (remember your final assessment should use your exam number)
Make sure HTML is selected as the output format

Click Create


 Save this file in your project_name/ folder with a short, sensible name such as wellbeing_report.qmd.
You should now have:
project_name/
  project_name.Rproj

 For now, keep the Quarto file that RStudio created, but we will replace its contents in the next exercise.

 In your wellbeing_report.qmd file, select and delete the default YAML block at the very top (everything between the first pair of --- lines).

Make sure the indents in your .qmd file look just like the code above! Sometimes copying and pasting code into a .qmd file changes the indentation of lines.
Then make the following edits:

Update the date string to today’s date.

 In one or two sentences: What does the format: section of the YAML control?

title: Practical
section: Exercise 4: Add a setup chunk that loads packages and data
text:
Exercise 4: Add a setup chunk that loads packages and data
Underneath the YAML header, we now want to add a setup chunk like the one shown in the seminar. This chunk will:

Load the packages you need
Read the wellbeing dataset from data/wellbeing_dataset.csv

Do some simple recoding
Set a default theme

 In your wellbeing_report.qmd, underneath the YAML header, add the following code chunk:
```{r}
#| label: setup
#| include: false
library(tidyverse)
library(patchwork)
library(viridis)
library(RColorBrewer)

wellbeing_df <- readr::read_csv("data/wellbeing_dataset.csv")

wellbeing_df <- wellbeing_df |>
  mutate(
    participant_group = factor(participant_group,
                               levels = c("student", "employed", "retired"))
  )

theme_set(theme_minimal(base_size = 14))
```
A few things to notice:


label: setup gives the chunk a clear name for error messages.


include: false means the code will run, but will not appear in the report, and any printed output from this chunk will be hidden.

The path "data/wellbeing_dataset.csv" is relative to the location of your .qmd file inside project_name/.

 Run the code chunk by clicking the green arrow in the upper right of the chunk. This runs the code within your RStudio session, so that you’ll be able to test run the code chunks you develop below.
Save the file, then click Render in RStudio.

If you get an error about a package not being found, use install.packages(), then try rendering again.

If you get a “file not found” error, double-check:

that wellbeing_dataset.csv is inside a folder called data

that the data folder is in the same folder as your report .qmd and .Rproj




 Once your report renders successfully, what do you see in the HTML document at this point?

section: Exercise 7: Create a multi-panel figure with chunk options
text:
Exercise 7: Create a multi-panel figure with chunk options
Now you’ll create a two-panel figure that explores how wellbeing and sleep differ by group.
 In the section # Group differences in wellbeing and sleep, add a new R chunk like the one below.
Edit the ggplot(...) contents to create bar plots with error bars showing wellbeing for each group and sleep for each group, as in the examples below.
Edit the fig-cap to include a brief, descriptive caption.
```{r}
#| label: fig-group-outcomes
#| echo: false
#| fig-cap: "..."
#| out-width: "80%"
#| fig-align: "center"

group_wellbeing <- ggplot(...)

group_sleep <- ggplot(...)

group_wellbeing / group_sleep
```







Figure 1: Wellbeing and sleep in participant groups.




 Test run the code by clicking the green arrow in the code chunk. You should see your plots (or an error message that you will need to fix). Try editing the code for your plots to polish them, e.g., by editing the axis labels, colors, etc, and running using the green arrow again until you’re happy with your choices.
 What patterns do you see in these plots? How do wellbeing and sleep vary across groups?
 Add Markdown text within this section to briefly describe the key patterns in these plots.
 Render the report and inspect:

Both the figures and text appear in this section
The code is hidden (echo: false)

The figure appears with a caption

The figure is not full-width because of out-width: "80%"

The figure is centered due to fig-align: "center"


 Experiment with different values of #| out-width: (e.g., "50%", "90%"). You can additionally add a line to control the figure height like this: #| fig-height: (e.g., 6, 7). Try rendering again with different values. Which width feels most readable in the rendered HTML report, and why?

title: Social Support, Therapy, and Wellbeing
text:
Introduction
Social support and access to therapy are both thought to play an important role in protecting mental health. This short report uses a simulated dataset of 400 adults to explore how perceived support and therapy use relate to wellbeing and loneliness.
Participants reported their support level (low, medium, or high), whether they were currently in therapy, and completed assessments of wellbeing and loneliness that were subsequently scored. The aim of the report is to summarise how these variables relate to one another.
This report first examines how wellbeing and loneliness differ across support levels, and then reveals the impact of therapy.
Data overview
The dataset contains the following key variables:


Support level (support_level): perceived social support (Low, Medium, High).

Therapy (therapy): whether the participant is currently receiving therapy (Yes/No).

Loneliness score (loneliness_score): higher values indicate greater loneliness.

Wellbeing score (wellbeing_score): higher values indicate better wellbeing.

In what follows, I focus on how wellbeing and loneliness vary across levels of support and therapy.
Support level affects wellbeing and loneliness
We first examine wellbeing and loneliness scores by support level. The pattern is clear: participants with low perceived support report the lowest wellbeing and highest loneliness. As support increases, wellbeing also increases, whereas loneliness decreases. Thus, support improves wellbeing and decreases loneliness.







Figure 1: Wellbeing scores by perceived support level.

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
So far, your consolidation exercises have been similar to the practical exercises, but with less guidance. To help you gain more independence in your work, this week’s consolidation exercise will be more open-ended.
In these consolidation exercises, you will take code from an earlier week and turn it into a short Quarto report, using the structure introduced in Week 8 and customization strategies introduced in Week 7. Practicing how to build a polished Quarto report will be useful preparation for both the final assessment and for communicating your work with other people.
You will:

Adapt plots and wrangling code from one earlier week: Week 3, 4, 5, or 6
Set up a project folder with a data/ subfolder
Create a Quarto report with a YAML header, setup chunk, and sections
Add chunk labels, chunk options, and inline code
Write short plain-language interpretations of your plots

You do not need to invent entirely new visualizations here. The goal is to practice turning code you have already written into a clear, reproducible report. To accomplish this goal, you can harness the polishing strategies from week 7 and the Quarto report approaches from week 8.






Key



These four symbols are used at the beginning of each instruction so you know where to carry out the instruction.
 Something you need to do on your computer. It may be opening programs or documents or locating a file.
 Something you should do in RStudio. It will often be typing a command or using the menus but might also be creating folders, locating or moving files.
 Something you should do in your browser on the internet. It may be searching for information, going to the VLE or downloading a file.
 A question for you to think about and answer. Record your answers in your report or script for future reference.





Choose an earlier practical or consolidation as the basis for this Week 8 report, such as:

Week 4 — Barplots

Week 5 — Relationships

Week 6 — Time series & line graphs

 Open the R script from that week. Quickly skim what you did.
 In a sentence or two, jot down: - Which dataset you plan to use - Which 2–3 plots you want to showcase in your report.
You can keep this plan outline short; it’s just to orient yourself.



Now you will create a fresh project specifically for this consolidation report, using the same structure as in the Week 8 practical.
 In RStudio, in the Files tab (Rstudio bottom right panel), create a new folder somewhere sensible (for example inside data-visualisation-in-r). Give it a clear name that relates to the graphs you will use in the report, such as consolidate8_barplots.
We will refer to this as project_name/.
This is the first step for building your project structure. Once you finish the additional setup steps below, your project structure should look like this:
project_name/
  project_name.Rproj
  consolidate8_report.qmd
  data/
    <one or more CSV files>
  
 Turn this folder into an RStudio Project:

Click the project dropdown in the top-right of RStudio (see the little icon with the blue cube)

Choose New Project → Existing Directory

Select your new project_name/ folder and click Create Project.

 Inside this project, create a subfolder called data.
 Copy the relevant CSV file(s) from the original week into this data folder.
 Why is it helpful to keep all files needed for your report (data, .qmd, project file) together in one project folder?



Now you will create the skeleton Quarto report.
 In RStudio (inside your new project):

Go to File → New File → Quarto Document…

Give it a clear title that mentions your topic and dataset, e.g.:

Engagement Across User Segments and Devices


List yourself as the author
Choose HTML as the format.

Click Create, then immediately save the file as consolidate8_report.qmd inside project_name/.

 Replace the default YAML at the top of the new .qmd with something similar to:
---
title: "Engagement Across User Segments and Devices"
author: "XXX"
date: "2025-11-15"
format:
  html:
    toc: true
    toc-depth: 2
    number-sections: false
    self-contained: true
execute:
  message: false
  warning: false
---
 What does the format: section of the YAML control?



Underneath the YAML, you now need a setup chunk that:

Loads any packages you need

Reads in the relevant dataset(s) from the data/ folder

Does any basic recoding (e.g., factor ordering) or processing

Optionally sets a default theme

 Test run the chunk within RStudio (using the green arrow). Fix any errors about missing packages or incorrect file paths.
 Save and Render your report.
 After your setup chunk runs successfully, what (if anything) do you see in the HTML report? Why?



Next, you’ll add a clear section structure using Markdown headings.
 Underneath your setup chunk, add headings like:
# Introduction

# Data overview

# [key result 1]

# [key result 2]

# Summary
You can adapt the key results to your topic, e.g., # App engagement by user segment



 In the # Data overview section, add a code chunk that shows the top few rows of the dataset and a brief Markdown description. Test run the chunk and render the file to check that everything runs / displays as intended.



Now the main step: adapt plots from your earlier script and translate them into Quarto chunks inside your report.
Aim for at least two plots that form a coherent story (e.g., different views of the same phenomenon, or related outcomes).
 For each plot you want to include:

Copy the ggplot code from your original script.
Paste it into an R chunk in the appropriate section of your report.
Add a chunk label and useful chunk options
Test run it to see how it looks.
Polish the plot using strategies from Advanced Customisation (Week 7)
Render and try adjusting the options controlling figure appearance until you’re happy with how it looks.
Add a brief description of the key result to the section.

 Repeat this for your other chosen plots. Remember that each of your code chunks should have a different label.



Considering your inspection of the dataset and the patterns:

Add a few sentences to the # Introduction section to introduce the dataset and the patterns that the report will depict.
Try including a sentence that notes the number of participants in the dataset (or some other useful bit of information) with inline code.
Add a few sentences to the # Summary section to summarise the patterns shown in the plots.




 Render your report and read it through from beginning to end. Imagine you are reading this report for the first time and are unfamiliar with the data / results.

Does it tell a clear and compelling story?
Are the figures easy to read?
Could you change anything to improve the narrative or plots further?

title: Overview
text:
This week you will be introduced to Shiny apps. Shiny apps allow you to build dynamic web apps in which people can interactively explore visualisations.

Learning objectives
The successful student will be able to:

Explain what a Shiny app is and why we might use one
Recognise the anatomy of a Shiny app:

ui, server, shinyApp(ui, server)

Build a simple interactive app that:

Uses selectInput() and checkboxInput()
Updates a ggplot using renderPlot() and plotOutput()

Organise app.R and data files in a project structure

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
From last time

Value of reproducible reports
Basic anatomy of a Quarto report
How to build a Quarto report combining prose, code and figures

YAML header, setup chunk, and body sections
Embedded code chunks with chunk options to control output

Project structure and workflow


Briefly remind students of Week 8:

They learned how to structure a Quarto report with YAML, a setup chunk, and a body that mixes text, code, and figures.
The therapy example report showed multi-panel figures and polished ggplots, using many of the visualisation techniques from Weeks 3–7.

Set up today as “the next step”: taking similar analyses and turning them into interactive tools.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Today

Why build a Shiny app?
Inspect a finished Shiny app
Basic anatomy of a Shiny app
How to build a simple Shiny app
Project structure and workflow


Give a quick overview of the plan:

First, motivation and context.
Then a quick look at what a finished Shiny app can do.
Then the “anatomy”: the parts that make up any Shiny app.
Then we build up a small app step by step.
Finally, we connect this to their project structure and the assessment.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Today

Why build a Shiny app?

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Why build a Shiny app?

Reports (Quarto) are great for:

Communicating a fixed story
Sharing key results and interpretations

Shiny apps are great for:

Exploring data interactively



Contrast Quarto and Shiny:

Quarto reports are like a polished article or mini-paper.
Shiny apps are like interactive dashboards: people can change inputs and immediately see updated plots.

Emphasise that both use the same R and ggplot skills they already have.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Why build a Shiny app?

Example applications in human data science:

Explore how outcomes change across groups or predictors
Live updates on projects as new data come in

Advantages:

Let collaborators, supervisors and users “play with” the data
Demonstrate findings in a more engaging way

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
A finished example

Can you recognize the plot elements?

What kind of plot is this?
What do you think is added to the ggplot code when the user checks the “Show individual data points” box?

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Today

Basic anatomy of a Shiny app

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
What is a web app?

A web application is:

A web page you can interact with (clicks, sliders, dropdowns)
The display updates automatically in response

Most things you interact with in a browser are web apps:

E.g., online forms



Keep this conceptual and light:

Emphasise that they already use web apps all the time (e.g., banking, booking systems).
The core idea: interactions in the browser trigger updates behind the scenes.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
section: How does a web app work?
text:
How does a web app work?

User interface (UI) that the user sees

What the user sees in the browser
Fixed (unchanging) elements such as a title for the webpage
User input options: dropdown menus, checkboxes, buttons
Plots shown as output in response to user inputs



Server (backend)

Code that does the work when the user interacts
Reads the user’s inputs and sends back updated outputs to the user



Relate this to everyday examples:

Entering values into tax software → server calculates refund.
Choosing filters on a data dashboard → server recomputes the plot.

Set up the parallel: Shiny will give us these two parts using R code.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
What is Shiny?


Shiny is an R package for building web apps:

You write the user interface (UI) in R
You write the server logic in R
Shiny connects them and runs the app

Builds on what you already know:

You stay inside RStudio and use a similar project workflow / setup
You can use the same kind of ggplot2 code to create plots in your apps




Underline the “no need to be a web developer” message:

They do not need to learn HTML, CSS, or JavaScript.
Shiny lets them re-use their R and ggplot skills.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Return to the example app
To create this app, under the hood, there is:


A bit of familiar code to read in the data
The ui, which shows the title, a user input dropdown menu and a user input checkbox, and a plot
The server logic that generates the plot, and customizes it based on the user’s input
A simple final line that launches the shiny app using the ui and server logic

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Today

How to build a simple Shiny app

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Today

How to build a simple Shiny app

Overview and basic skeleton

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Building a Shiny app: Overview

A file called app.R that lives in your project folder
You can run the app locally in RStudio

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Building a Shiny app: Overview
Within this file, you:


Include any initial setup steps, such as loading libraries, reading in data
Build the ui specify what is shown to the user: fixed content, user input options, dynamic outputs
Build the server logic as a function that uses user inputs from the ui to generate dynamic outputs in the ui
Include a simple final line to launch the app

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Inputs and outputs

Inputs

The ui defines user input options (e.g., checkboxes, menus)
The user’s input (e.g., their dropdown menu choice) is stored as part of an object called input
The server can read and use the input object’s parts

Outputs

The server function uses the input object’s parts
Includes code that uses those parts to create outputs, such as a plot that updates any time the user input changes

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Building a Shiny app: Skeleton
library(shiny) # Always needed!
library(useful_stuff)

data <- read_csv("data/...")

...

Let’s make this all concrete.
Here’s the basic skeleton of the code you’d write in your shiny app.
We would typically start off with some set up steps, like loading in libraries and data. We will ALWAYS need at the very least to load the shiny library to make the shiny app run. And we typically have other libraries as well.
We would then typically read in data. As we did in our quarto projects, it’s useful to keep the data you need in a subfolder within the same folder as your shiny app. In the future, in your careers, you might want to do clever things like pull data from the internet, but we’ll keep this simple and always just use data that we actually have.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Building a Shiny app: Skeleton
library(shiny) # Always needed!
library(useful_stuff)

data <- read_csv("data/...")

ui <- fluidPage(
  # UI elements go here
)

...

The next thing we do is create the ui.
We’ll always do this using this same basic skeleton. We create an object called ui, and we do that using a function called fluidPage.
Then we fill the contents of that function with everything we want in our user interface.
For example, in our example app, this might include the title of the app, the dropown menu and checkbox, and the plot.
We’ll dive into how to specify the contents of the UI in a moment.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Building a Shiny app: Skeleton
library(shiny) # Always needed!
library(useful_stuff)

data <- read_csv("data/...")

ui <- fluidPage(
  # UI elements go here
)

server <- function(input, output, session) { 
  ... # server logic goes here 
  }

The next big step is to define the server.
As I mentioned, this will be a function that uses the user’s input to dynamically generate and update the output that they see, like generating the boxplot where the user can dynamically change the outcome variable and add points.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Building a Shiny app: Skeleton
library(shiny) # Always needed!
library(useful_stuff)

data <- read_csv("data/...")

ui <- fluidPage(
  # UI elements go here
)

server <- function(input, output, session) { 
  ... # server logic goes here 
  }


shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)

And then finally, we add one simple line at the end that tells shiny to combine the ui and server into a running app

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Today

How to build a simple Shiny app

Overview and basic skeleton
Populate the ui

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Populate UI
Start with a basic UI using fluidPage()
ui <- fluidPage(
  # UI elements go here
)

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Populate UI: Functions
Add elements using functions
ui <- fluidPage(
  # Each UI element is added with a function
  # Different functions add different kinds of UI elements, e.g.,
  # -- title
  # -- user input options
  # -- plot
)

We can add UI elements using functions
There are different functions we can use to add different kinds of elements

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Populate UI: Fixed elements
Add fixed (unchanging) elements
library(shiny)

ui <- fluidPage(
  titlePanel("Support, Therapy, and Wellbeing: Interactive"),

  p("Use the controls below to explore how outcomes vary across support levels.")
)

We can start by adding some simple, unchanging elements for the user to see.
For example, we’ll use a titlePanel function to add a title
And a little paragraph (p function) to add a bit of extra text to show the user.
For now, there are no inputs or outputs — just static text.
Similar to how your quarto projects had a title and some introductory text.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Populate UI: Inputs
Different functions add different types of user input controls
The option specified by the user is stored as part of an input object
ui <- fluidPage(
  titlePanel("Support, Therapy, and Wellbeing: Interactive"),

  p("Use the controls below to explore how outcomes vary across support levels."),
  
  someInput( 
    inputId = "some_name", # name of the part in the input object
    label   = "Some label:", # label shown to the user
    ...
  )
)

Now we’re ready to start adding user input controls
So these could be dropdown menus, checkboxes, buttons, and so on.
Remember, as I noted before, the user’s choice for these inputs will be stored as part of an object called “input”.
And each type of user input control has its own function.
Right now I’ve just put a generic placeholder in called someInput This isn’t a real function, it’s just to show you the general format
At minimum, every input function you use should specify at least these first two arguments.
First, the inputId. This argument will be the name of the part where the user’s choice is stored in the input object. This will allow us to read and use the user’s choice in our server code later.
Second, the label to show the user. This is the label that the user will see on the screen, like the label of the dropdown menu or checkbox.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Populate UI: Inputs
Different functions add different types of user input controls
The option specified by the user is stored as part of an input object
ui <- fluidPage(
  titlePanel("Support, Therapy, and Wellbeing: Interactive"),

  p("Use the controls below to explore how outcomes vary across support levels."),

  selectInput(
    inputId = "outcome",
    label   = "Outcome to plot:",
    ...
  )
)

For example, our example app has a dropdown menu. This dropdown menu is added using this selectInput function.
Remember, that dropdown menu allows the user to choose which outcome variable to plot. So, I’ve set the inputID as outcome, and given it this user-friendly label that tells them they can use the menu to choose an outcome to plot.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Populate UI: Inputs
Different functions add different types of user input controls
The option specified by the user is stored as part of an input object
ui <- fluidPage(
  titlePanel("Support, Therapy, and Wellbeing: Interactive"),

  p("Use the controls below to explore how outcomes vary across support levels."),

  selectInput(
    inputId = "outcome",
    label   = "Outcome to plot:",
    ... WHAT ELSE???
  )
)

But this isn’t enough to define everything about that dropdown menu.
What else might we need to specify here?
(dropdown options, default option)

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Populate UI: Inputs
Different functions add different types of user input controls
This will add a part to the input object called outcome
The value of outcome will depend on the user’s choice
ui <- fluidPage(
  titlePanel("Support, Therapy, and Wellbeing: Interactive"),

  p("Use the controls below to explore how outcomes vary across support levels."),

  selectInput(
    inputId = "outcome",
    label   = "Outcome to plot:",
    choices = c(
      "Wellbeing score"  = "wellbeing_score",
      "Loneliness score" = "loneliness_score"
    ),
    selected = "wellbeing_score"
  )
)

So we have additional arguments for our dropdown menu input.
One is called choices. Here, we define a vector that includes both: the option that the user will see in the menu, and the value that we want to store when the user chooses an option.
And the other is called selected. Here, we specify the default value we want to use before the user has selected anything, when they first open the app.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Populate UI: Inputs
Different functions add different types of user input controls
ui <- fluidPage(
  titlePanel("Support, Therapy, and Wellbeing: Interactive"),

  p("Use the controls below to explore how outcomes vary across support levels."),

  selectInput(
    inputId = "outcome",
    label   = "Outcome to plot:",
    choices = c(
      "Wellbeing score"  = "wellbeing_score",
      "Loneliness score" = "loneliness_score"
    ),
    selected = "wellbeing_score"
  ),
  
  checkboxInput(
    inputId = "show_points",
    label   = "Show individual data points",
    value   = FALSE
  )
)

We can continue using the same approach to add other kinds of input optins.
Here I’ve added that checkbox option from the example app.
Note that I used a different function to create the checkbox.
I’ve given it its own id and label.
And since this is a checkbox, not a dropdwn menu, it has its own additional arguments.
Here, I specify the default value to store when the box is unchecked.
That default value is FALSE, meaning no, don’t show data points on the boxplot.
Again, use these values later in our server code to generate the plot based on the user’s input.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Populate UI: Inputs
Different functions add different types of user input controls

More options (“widgets”)

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Populate UI: Outputs
Now we tell the UI where the plot will appear
We refer to the name of the plot we will create using the server code
ui <- fluidPage(
  ...

  plotOutput("support_plot")
)

Explain:

plotOutput("support_plot") creates a space in the UI where Shiny will display the plot.
The string "support_plot" must match the name we’ll use on the server: output$support_plot.

Reinforce the mapping: output name in UI ↔︎ output name in server.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Today

How to build a simple Shiny app

Overview and basic skeleton
Populate the ui
Build server code



Now is when we switch over to building that server logic.
Here, we’ll use the inputs from the user to create that plot, So that the UI can then show the plot to the user.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Build Server Code
Server is a function that uses inputs to generate outputs
server <- function(input, output, session) {

  # Server logic will go here

}

Point out:

Every Shiny app server is a function with at least these arguments:

input : list of all input values
output : list where we store outputs
session: information about the current session (not needed today)


For now, the body is empty — no outputs are defined yet.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Build Server Code
We define an output called support_plot using renderPlot()
Currently static (not responsive to user input)
server <- function(input, output, session) {

  output$support_plot <- renderPlot({

    ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = support_level,
                           y = wellbeing_score)) + # STATIC!
      geom_boxplot(aes(fill = support_level),
                   alpha       = 0.8,
                   width       = 0.6,
                   show.legend = FALSE) +
      scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "plasma") +
      labs(
        x = "Support level",
        y = "Wellbeing score" # STATIC!
      ) +
      coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0, 100))

  })

}

To start off with, let’s try just putting some familiar ggplot code here.
This is the same kind of ggplot code you’ve been learning how to write throughout the module, just wrapped inside renderPlot({ ... }).
At this stage, the app will show a wellbeing boxplot that does not yet respond to inputs.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Build Server Code: Incorporate Inputs

Remember:

ui stored user options as parts of an object called input
we gave those parts names using inputId

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Build Server Code: Incorporate Inputs

We can now reference these input parts in our server code:

use dollar sign notation
e.g., to reference the outcome part: input$outcome

The value of that part will be based on the user’s input

e.g., if the user selected wellbeing as the outcome, then
input$outcome will be wellbeing_score

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Build Server Code: Incorporate Inputs

Our approach:

Check input part values
Use them in our server code to control our outputs

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Build Server Code: Incorporate Inputs

Some basic programming with if-statements:
if(input$part == "some_value") {

  ...if TRUE, do this...

}

Today, I’ll show you a very basic way to do this using some basic programing called an if-statement.
If-statements are common throughout programming languages - this is a very basic thing you often want to tell a computer to do.
Instead of having a computer always do a PARTICULAR THING, you often want it to check some condition, and then say IF that condition met, THEN do something.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Build Server Code: Incorporate Inputs

This is just one way to use inputs!
Showing for simplicity: avoid overburdening with new concepts
More approaches can be found in your reading (especially chapter 4)

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Build Server Code: Incorporate Inputs
Make the plot respond to input$outcome:
server <- function(input, output, session) {

  output$support_plot <- renderPlot({
    
    # If the user chose wellbeing_score...
    if(input$outcome == "wellbeing_score") {
      
      # Then create output_plot as a boxplot with wellbeing_score on the y-axis
      output_plot <- therapy_df %>%
        ggplot(aes(x = support_level, y = wellbeing_score)) +
        geom_boxplot(
          aes(fill = support_level),
          alpha       = 0.8,
          width       = 0.6,
          show.legend = FALSE
        ) +
        scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "plasma") +
        labs(
          x = "Support level",
          y = "Wellbeing score"
        ) +
        coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0, 100))
    } else {
      
      # Otherwise (i.e., if the user did NOT choose wellbeing_score), 
      # create the plot using loneliness_score as the y-axis variable
      output_plot <- therapy_df %>%
        ggplot(aes(x = support_level, y = loneliness_score)) +
        geom_boxplot(
          aes(fill = support_level),
          alpha       = 0.8,
          width       = 0.6,
          show.legend = FALSE
        ) +
        scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "plasma") +
        labs(
          x = "Support level",
          y = "Loneliness score"
        ) +
        coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0, 100))
    }
    
}

This looks like a lot of code, but really it’s just two chunks of ggplot code -
One to run and store as the output if the user selected wellbeing, and another one to run if the user selected something else.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Build Server Code: Incorporate Inputs
Can chain if… else… endlessly
But might want a more efficient approach with > 2 options!
server <- function(input, output, session) {

  output$support_plot <- renderPlot({
    
    # If the user chose wellbeing_score...
    if(input$outcome == "wellbeing_score") {
      
      # Then create output_plot as a boxplot with wellbeing_score on the y-axis
      output_plot <- therapy_df %>%
        ggplot(aes(x = support_level, y = wellbeing_score)) +
        geom_boxplot(
          aes(fill = support_level),
          alpha       = 0.8,
          width       = 0.6,
          show.legend = FALSE
        ) +
        scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "plasma") +
        labs(
          x = "Support level",
          y = "Wellbeing score"
        ) +
        coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0, 100))
    } else {
      
      # Otherwise (i.e., if the user did NOT choose wellbeing_score), 
      # create the plot using loneliness_score as the y-axis variable
      output_plot <- therapy_df %>%
        ggplot(aes(x = support_level, y = loneliness_score)) +
        geom_boxplot(
          aes(fill = support_level),
          alpha       = 0.8,
          width       = 0.6,
          show.legend = FALSE
        ) +
        scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "plasma") +
        labs(
          x = "Support level",
          y = "Loneliness score"
        ) +
        coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0, 100))
    }
    
}

Suppose your dropdown menu had more than just 2 options. For example, suppose we had 3 or more outcome variables that users could choose between.
We could keep extending this approach and chain if else statements however much we want. But this would make our code long and tedious.
So this is a simple but potentially tedious approach. There are other more efficient approaches.

Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Build Server Code: Incorporate Inputs
Optionally adding points based on checkbox
Remember:

our ui code stored the user’s choice in the checkbox as input$show_points
by default, the value of input$show_points was FALSE
if the user checks the box, it switches to TRUE

text:
Today

How to build a simple Shiny app


Now we have all the parts of our app. Let’s just review what we’ve built.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Building a Shiny app: Skeleton
library(shiny) # Always needed!
library(useful_stuff)

data <- read_csv("data/...")

ui <- fluidPage(
  # UI elements: fixed content, UI input options, dynamic output
)

server <- function(input, output, session) { 
  ... # server function used inputs to generate dynamic output
  }


shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server) # connect the ui and server

To go back to ur basic skeleton…
We have some setup steps at the beginning to load packages and read in data.
We specified the parts of our UI – Some fixed content like a title – Interactive user input options - dropdown menu and checkbox – A dynamic output
We built our server code – Used user inputs to dynamically generate an output plot
And then lastly, we just have this final line that’s needed to connect the ui and server.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Today

Why build a Shiny app?
Inspect a finished Shiny app
Basic anatomy of a Shiny app
How to build a simple Shiny app
Project structure and workflow

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Project structure for Shiny apps
A simple recommended structure:
data-vis/
  data-vis.Rproj
  data/
    therapy_dataset.csv
  app.R

Explain:

Keep app.R in the project root alongside their Quarto files.
Keep data in a data/ folder, using relative paths.
This mirrors the structure used for their reports.

Highlight that this structure will make it easier to zip the whole project for submission.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
section: How to create app.R in RStudio
text:
How to create app.R in RStudio

Have your folder and RStudio project setup
Go to File → New File → R Script
Save the file as app.R in the project root
Edit:

Setup
UI (text, inputs, plotOutput)
Server (renderPlot code)

Try running by clicking Run App in the top-right of the script pane


Stress that they do not need to use “New Shiny Web App”:

Creating a plain R script and saving it as app.R is simpler and keeps everything in one project.
This is also what you will expect in the final assessment.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Troubleshooting: common issues

Package not found

Add library(shiny) and other libraries at the top of app.R

File not found

Check the path to your data and that it’s inside the project (e.g., data/therapy_dataset.csv)

Input or output not found

Do inputId and output$... names match between UI and server?



Encourage students to read error messages:

Errors often tell them whether the problem is in the UI or server, and which name is missing.

Reassure them that this is normal; debugging is part of the process.

title: Week 9 Seminar: Shiny Apps 1
text:
Summary


What a Shiny app is and why we might use one
The anatomy of a Shiny app (user interface and server)
Built a simple interactive app with ui and server that dynamically generates a plot
Organise app.R and data files in a project structure


Close the loop:

Connect back to the final assessment: this is roughly the level and structure you expect, with Week 10 adding more advanced layout and features.
Invite questions, especially around the UI/server mapping and how to think about inputs and outputs.
